But can you just talk us how you -- talk us through how you calculate, what is the appropriate cost of capital for a standalone Investment Bank, since they seem to have gone the way of the dinosaur here?

Well, I'm not sure this is a dinosaur, I think it's the future, so there will more dinosaurs come to follow. We do -- we have a risk adjusted cost of equity framework internally where we -- whereby we calculate what we believe are the appropriate hurdle rates for all the various businesses, and based on last year's plan that was 13.4% for the IB as a whole. I do believe that this is coming to drop because we actually have less risk, less leverage and therefore the hurdle rate needs to come down a bit.

And then on the leverage ratio and how it develops, I think we have always said from the outset that we do acknowledge that we had too high a leverage, that's why we have very substantially reduced our balance sheet and that's why we always felt that we are aligned with the notion that in order to return confidence to the financial system we will need more capital and we need also an agreement that leverage can't grow indefinitely. That's why we felt that we are aligned with the Swiss regulatory authorities who spearheaded this very, very early in the process.

As in Switzerland, it was obvious that one has to be careful not to create an instrument which then puts a restriction on the very fundamental activity of bank, of lending money. And I think that's the dilemma everybody is in here now. On the one-hand strength in balance sheets needs to return, on the other-hand nobody wants to undermine the abilities of the banks to lend money. And I think all the regulatory authorities around the world will strike a careful balance between these two objectives of achieving more capital, lower leverage but not undermining the very fundamental purpose of the banking system in funding the economy. I do expect that we will find global consistency because I think the regulatory authorities around the world are highly committed to come up with consistent regulation around the world.
Okay, thank you.
Next question please.
Next question from Mr. Kinner Lakhani, RBS. Please go ahead, sir.

Yes, hi. I apologize in advance for a couple of technical questions. Firstly, I just want to understand the reclassification of the monoline exposure and how it is then treated in your monoline disclosure on slide 44? My previous understanding was consistent that you cannot transfer it to a bad bank, but I also understand that you could not transfer it to the loan book. So, I wonder if you could just give me a little bit to understand that?

And secondly to come back to the shareholders' equity question, you may have already explained this, but I'm trying to understand the 3.6 billion decline in the share premium related to the MCNs placed with the Swiss Confederation, and how we should treat that in relation to looking at a pro forma shareholders' equity? I think so far you've said we add 6 billion to the reported number.

Okay. On monolines first, everything which is a derivative comp we reclassified, and that means only a part of the underlying assets which are actually securities can be reclassified and held for sale. And as I said, this refers predominately to collateralized loan obligations of very high quality which we feel are appropriate to do so. And the rest are either synthetic CLO underlying which is a derivative contract and of course the monoline insurance contract itself, which is a credit default swap, cannot be reclassified and has to be treated under fair value accounting, which we did.

So what you see on the table is the underlying – it's the underlying exposure, exactly consistent with what we did before, where we have securities underlying. We would hold these underlying at their carrying value on a loans and receivables basis. Shareholder equity?
Yes, if you ask technical questions, you're going to get a technical answer.

The way the MCN was accounted for was that it was deemed by and large, a compound financial instrument with a debt host complicated. And the postings on inception of that are to debit the cash account with the 6 billion we get in. And then a debt component is set up which is the carrying value of the liability. Now because the coupon is quite high, you have to split the coupon between debt and an equity component and that has an implied debt component of 7.733 billion. So you credit debt with 7.733.

You then have to take the derivative component which is the option – or the two options within the MCN, because it has a booster option and a conversion option. And that's booked in negative replacement values, and that was 1.425 billion, also a credit. And the debit is the remaining equity component and that's the debit that goes to share premium pending the issue of the shares. And that was a debit of 3.158 billion. Now when the shares are issued, you credit share premium and credit share capital. And that will back out that share premium amount.
By 6 billion in total?
Yes, that's right. So, both sides of the balance sheet that should add up to 9.158, so you issue 6 billion and you get to book 9.158 --
Okay --
But I didn't write IFRS.
Now to relieve us from accounting, can we go to the next question?
Next question from Ms. Fiona Swaffield, Execution. Please go ahead, madam.

Hi, two questions if possible, in the past you've talked about running with a very large liquidity buffer in the Investment Bank which has hurt fixed income. And I think in the last call you said it was costing you about 100 basis points. I wondered if you could talk about whether you brought liquidity buffer down, and whether you're making more money on that in 2009, because of where the yield curve is, so to what extent that will help fixed income?

And then the second is on the gross margin in the private bank where it -- I think recurring has gone down to 70 bps. Do you think that that's actually somewhat inflated because of the timing of the assets coming down, so the underlying margins are even worse, and do you think that could get worse before they get better? Because I think you were pretty negative on the margin outlook previously.
Yeah first of all what was the one, the...
The liquidity buffer.

Liquidity buffer, point is, yes it's still around 100 basis points and actually it has increased, has become bigger. And we remain very, very cautious and continue to carry very, very large liquidity up until the point we really feel that stability has returned into the financial markets. And so far it will obviously cost us money, but we believe it's money well spent. It will not be part of the fixed income result going forward.
We're going to move it into corporate center and we're going to charge the Investment Bank for two thirds of it and Business Banking or Swiss Bank, as it's going to be called, one third.
Could I just come back to why it's still costing so much? Because I thought the yield curve had slightly flattened, or is it just the duration, you've got some duration --
It's a duration mismatch.
It is a duration mismatch, yeah
Okay.

And the gross margin, you have an effect. Obviously you're right, delaying that, because it's based on monthly, mid month or end of month averages when we calculate the fees. But at the same time you have seen currency movements in our favor which create a positive fluctuation so we are not particularly negative on a gross margin outlook from where we currently are.

Could you explain – I meant to ask as well in terms of the structure of the assets, so one issue is deleveraging but in terms of clients moving out of more complicated high margin products, do you think we've now at 10% of assets from 20, have we got there in terms of derisking?

Look it's hard to say. A lot of that has already happened because people that are moving out of discretionary products were redeeming complex products, are using structured products less frequently and we clearly see that as a result of the crisis that this has had an impact. To what extent this might continue or not, I think we have seen a very substantial part of that happening in last year and would not expect a very substantial continuation of that trend from the current levels.
Thanks.
Next question.
Next question from Goran Mijuk, Dow Jones. Please go ahead sir.

Yeah, good morning. My question is basically related to your inflows in January, you said that you've reversed the trend last month, so maybe you could just give us a slight outlook of what you expect the next months to be, and what you've done in January to actually reverse the trend has been quite dramatic in the fourth quarter?

I think we are not going to comment on post January, that's what we said. But looking at it is never an action in one month which triggers money in the same month. This is always lagging many, many actions cumulative effect of all the actions we take, and what you actually see is there was this massive uncertainty but there was a very drastic and substantial action in October which has essentially demonstrated that the bank is sound and safe, and this has brought back the trust of clients in this very difficult time.
Yeah, when you say trust of clients, do you refer both to wealthy clients and as well as retail clients in Switzerland. Have you seen...

Well I could say that it will take us longer to regain the trust and confidence of our retail clients in Switzerland. That's clearly a longer-term issue and part of what we have done in terms of reorganizing ourselves should help actually accomplish that.
Now, thank you very much and we now have more questions from the audience here. I have seen Mr. you had a question?

I would like to ask, for those of us who are not very familiar with these accounting tricks about the regulatory basis of this reclassification. If I have understood this correctly you can just decide that you want to hold to majority a position that was a trading position before, and then forget about valuation at the market price and put in just whatever value your specialists believe.
Now if this is correct, my second question is why haven't you done this before and spared us all these horrible figures.

Well thanks for the question. It's actually not that we can just put in the value we wanted. There are very important conditions which need to be met. First of all these are businesses which we exit, so there is no longer any trading.

And secondly there is also no market, which provides you really with any reliable value in a very liquid environment. You can, however, only do that at the value we had it on the book. So we can't put a different value than the one we actually had on the 30th of September on our book, that's the value at which it's transferred.

And then thirdly you then have to verify if this carrying value is supported by the underlying asset. So you made actually a fundamental analysis the way you would do it in a credit impairment test. So is it likely that all of these -- of the value at which we hold it will actually be returned over the lifetime of the instrument through the cash flows.

And that's very thoroughly vetted but that's what we have to done in a very, very thorough procedure. Why did we not do that before? Because only on the 13th of October, the International Accounting Standard Board has actually allowed a financial institution under IFRS to apply these options and under these very restrictive conditions, in order to exactly not do what you implied in the question that you could put on – a specialist could just put on a value. That's not what is possible in this procedure. Yes, last question over there.

Question on the SNB transaction again, you're now transferring less assets to the SNB and it looks like you're keeping the higher quality assets. The 10% rule of underlying equity hasn't changed, for me that looks like the deal has become a little bit more attractive for UBS, is that a fair assessment?

No, I think that's an unfair assessment. It is not the case -- as you have seen, we have actually taken 600 million additional provisions on these assets, which shows you that we just felt with the treatment we have now chosen to apply, and the additional provisions we have taken, that we can deal with this problem ourselves so to speak and do not need this facility with the Swiss National Bank. That's one thing.

And secondly, the portfolio is still a diversified portfolio which is not materially affected by that. And thirdly, as you have recognized there is also an underlying monoline exposure, the green shoe, which we have taken back in conjunction with this monoline. So I think the nature of the transaction is exactly the same as it was before with the same purpose and the same risk characteristics.
Yes, .

In Germany you said that you get the of CHF 3 million from the Swiss Confederation. Now as I understand you have here in the income statement you have tax expense minus CHF 6 billion. So, is there another or principally when do you pay tax again in Switzerland? So I think next 10 years or there will be no taxes or what is the horizon here?
I defer to the CFO. We had another tax credit of 1.7 billion this quarter which adds together with previous tax credit.
We did and one of the differences this quarter is that it's not just Swiss. In fact we had losses in a number of jurisdictions against which we've taken tax credits. So it's not just Switzerland.
And the sooner we are returning to profitability and the higher it is the higher the likelihood that we'll pay soon tax. Clearly the amortization of these tax credits takes some time.
Yeah. It will do.
No, I think that's very -- that's much sooner.
It will be largely sooner, yeah.
Yeah.
Okay. I think with that we can close the session. Thank you very much for the questions and for your presence here. Thank you.
